title: 110_hr2572
content: The Nurse Loan Forgiveness Act of 2007 may be cited as the ``Nurse Loan Forgiveness Act of 2007''. The Congress acknowledges the urgent need for nurses in the healthcare system, with statistics showing a significant shortage of registered nurses. Research indicates a high demand for healthcare services, including hospitals and prescription drugs, despite a decrease in the number of entry-level registered nurses. The Department of Labor projects a 29 percent increase in the need for nurses nationwide from 2004 to 2014, with 40 percent of all registered nurses estimated to be older than age 50 by 2010. About 16 percent of registered nurses in 2004 have chosen not to practice in the field. Loan forgiveness program established for nurses under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The section aims to encourage individuals to enter and stay in the nursing profession, reward experienced nurses for mentoring new nurses, and reduce student debt through loan forgiveness. The Secretary can forgive student loan debt for eligible borrowers who serve for five years after the enactment of this section. The Secretary can forgive student loan debt for eligible borrowers who serve for five years after the enactment of this section through a program that assumes the obligation to repay qualified loan amounts and cancels loans made under part D of this title. Loan amounts under section 428C can only be considered qualified loan amounts if used to repay specific types of loans for eligible borrowers. The Secretary can provide loan forgiveness to eligible borrowers who have worked as registered nurses or nursing instructors for at least one year, have a Masters of Science in Nursing if qualifying as an instructor, and are not in default on a loan. The Secretary can forgive loan obligations for eligible borrowers who have worked as registered nurses or nursing instructors for specific durations, with forgiveness amounts ranging from $2,000 to $5,000 based on years of employment. Borrowers must not be in default on their loans to qualify for forgiveness. Borrowers seeking loan forgiveness must submit a complete application to the Secretary, who will grant forgiveness on a first-come, first-served basis. The Secretary can create necessary regulations, and borrowers cannot receive benefits from both this section and another specified act for the same service. Authorization of appropriations is granted for fiscal year 2008 and the following 5 years to carry out loan forgiveness benefits under this section. Borrowers cannot receive benefits for both types of employment described in subsections (c)(1)(A) and (c)(1)(B).
